textMap.PRIMARY: 4. Joe and Juliana go for a drive
5. Juliana and Joe return to Canon City
6. The Smith family sits down for breakfast
8. Juliana chats with a man reading a Bible
10. Tagomi is informed about the film smuggling
11. Juliana discusses the book of Ecclesiastes
12. John discusses Joe's assignment with Erich
16. John is briefed on the findings from the attack
18. Frank tries to break his chains
19. Joe continues to spy on Juliana
22. The Crothers are taken into custody
24. Joe continues his vigil for his contact
29. John learns more about Joe's mysterious contact
30. Frank is taken away as Juliana meets with her contact

accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Frank Frink. acted by Rupert Evans
Inspector Kido. acted by Joel de la Fuente
Juliana Crain. acted by Alexa Davalos
Joe Blake. acted by Luke Kleintank
Lem Washington. acted by Rick Worthy
Helen Smith. acted by Chelah Horsdal
John Smith. acted by Rufus Sewell
Oberfeuhrer Oliver Diels. acted by Alex Zahara
Ambassador Hugo Reiss. acted by Bernhard Forcher
Nobusuke Tagomi. acted by Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa
Ed McCarthy. acted by DJ Qualls
Harlan Wyndam Matson. acted by Jack Kehler
Lawrence Klemm. acted by Steve Byers
Rudolph Wegener. acted by Carsten Norgaard

textMap.PRIMARY: Out of Sight, Out of Mind

Located in Burnaby, BC the Canon City set is built on the same backlot used in the 2009 film, "The Watchman." This differs from the Canon City location of the pilot which was filmed in Roslyn, Washington.
The filming location where Joe and Juliana watch the sunrise is the Cleveland Dam located in North Vancouver, BC.

Thomas Smith is wearing an Americanized Nazi Youth Uniform. The design in the world of "The Man in the High Castle," is inspired by the historical Hitlerjugend uniform. The diamond shaped patch on his pocket with solid red above, red stripes below and a swastika at the center represents their motto "Blood and Honor." The armband is a junior version of the adult armband seen on all Nazi officers. Above the armband is his troop patch reading, "Long Island." Thomas also carries a small dagger that Obergruppenfuehrer Smith wore in the pilot as he is trying his best to emulate his father.

Hitler firmly believed that the future of Germany was in its children. Created in the 1920s, the Hitler Youth (Hitlerjugend) was seen as a very important component to Hitler's success. As the only legal youth group outside of schools (which were also controlled by the Nazi regime), children joined at 10 years old and were members until they reached 18. They were instilled with a tireless work ethic, indoctrinated into a culture of racism, and taught to despise any opposition to Hitler and his ideology. The female wing of the Nazi party's youth movement was called The League of German Maidens (Bund Deutscher Maedel) where girls were trained for their roles within German society - as wife, mother and homemaker.

Hitler recognized that to achieve long-term control of his people he would have to gain control of their minds, starting within schools. He wanted school to provide students with 'healthy' minds and bodies rather than just knowledge. He believed that weakness should be hammered away, and wanted to create a brutal and domineering youth to help create his New Order. Teachers were required to join the National Socialist Teachers League and swear allegiance to Hitler. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," schools in the Greater Nazi Reich would be run as Hitler ran them in Nazi Germany.

Frank is taken into custody by the Kempetai, the Japanese secret military police. The officer harassing Frank is a sergeant in the prison. He and his men are under the orders of Chief Inspector Kido, the highest ranking officer in Kempetai headquarters.

While prisoners in concentration camps were predominantly Jewish, there were also large numbers of Romani people interned by the Nazis, as well as political opponents, criminals, Eastern European intellectuals, Catholic clergy members, and Jehovah's witnesses.  Homosexuals and people with disabilities were also sent to the camps as Hitler viewed them as a genetic hindrance to the growth of the Nazi population.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," "American Reich" is a hugely popular television series within the Greater Nazi Reich. It centers around the solving of local crimes by two clearly Aryan detectives, Ralph Foreman and Hans Dekker, who operate strictly within the Nazi moral code. The characters promote putting society first, even before family, and doing what is best for the greater good of the Reich. Played by two well-known stars of the Greater Nazi Reich, this detective duo is much loved throughout the Reich globally.

The exterior filming location of The Japanese Authority Building is New Westminster City Hall in New Westminster, BC. The exterior was augmented using CGI and all interiors were shot either on stage or at other locations.

Ecclesiastes is considered one of 7 Wisdom Books of the Bible. It is included in the Christian faith's Old Testament as well as the Hebrew Bible. Ecclesiastes contains 12 chapters and although the author doesn't directly name himself it is generally believed to be Solomon, "the son of David, king of Jerusalem."

Born in 1897, Joseph Goebbels earned a PhD in philosophy in 1920 from Heidelberg University. Unable to serve in the German army due to a clubfoot which inhibited his ability to walk, he worked in a bank. The feeling of physical inferiority and rejection from the army is said to have turned him into a very embittered man - referred to by other Nazis as the Poison Dwarf. In 1933 he was appointed Minister of Enlightenment and Propaganda. When Russia invaded Berlin in 1945, he poisoned his 6 children and had he and his wife shot.

Little has changed in the Neutral Zone, since it was left predominantly ungoverned by the Nazis and Japanese. Most evidently here is the music, which has had neither German nor Japanese influences, and remains true to the American music of the 1940s.

Martin Bormann, Hitler's 'deputy' from 1941, saw Nazism and Christianity as incompatible and had a particular loathing for the Semitic origins of Christianity. The concept of 'Positive Christianity' was strongly supported by the Nazi movement, particularly by Alfred Rosenberg, a German philosopher who strongly supported the Nazi ideology.  Advocating 'Positive Christianity', he planned the "extermination of the foreign Christian faiths imported into Germany", and for the Bible and Christian cross to be replaced with Mein Kampf and the swastika. He believed that Protestant and Catholic churches had distorted Christianity, moving the perception of Jesus away from the Aryan view.  Rosenberg wanted to use the idea of positive Christianity as a transition to easily move towards a more fully racialist faith.  While Hitler supported and approved of Rosenberg's ideas, he distanced himself to some extent in order to maintain the support of conservative Christians. However, in the world of "The Man in the High Castle," with the power that Hitler has gained, he gradually closed this distance resulting in full support of Rosenberg's racialist faith. Therefore, in "The Man in the High Castle," the Bible as we know it was banned throughout the Reich.

The line "Evil triumphs only when the good do nothing," was inspired by a quote from the Anglo-Irish politician, Edmund Burke - "The only thing necessary for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing."

Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Minister for Propaganda, had control over all forms of communication in Nazi Germany and ensured that any influences he deemed threatening to the Nazi regime were heavily censored or eliminated altogether. Art, books, movies, music, radio, and newspaper all underwent censorship. While materials by Jewish writers and artists were swiftly banned, purely due to the ethnicity of its creator, non-Jewish materials were also banned if the ideas dissented from the Nazi ideal. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," Mark Twain would have been a banned author. The essay he wrote in 1880 titled 'The Awful German Language', probably wasn't looked upon favorably by the Nazis.

Taken from Ecclesiastes 12:5 - "Also when they shall be afraid of that which is high, and fears shall be in the way, and the almond tree shall flourish, and the grasshopper shall be a burden, and desire shall fail: because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the streets:"

This song, Sukiyaki, spent three weeks at the top of the billboard charts in 1963 and was already a huge hit in Japan before it was released in America. It symbolized Japan's return to the world after the destruction of WWII. It is sung by 21 year old Kyu Sakamoto, who in many ways, was the face of post war Japan. The story of the song however, is one of sadness and loss, looking back on the failure of the protest movement in Japan in the 1950s when there was still an American military presence there. It left many young people feeling disillusioned about the impact of protesting. The lyrics of the song describe trying to stem tears while looking to the future for good fortune, looking back in sorrow, whilst also hopeful that the future will be better.
Tagomi's lapel pin is that of the Japanese Pacific States flag. He wears it as a representation of pride for his country.

Zyklon B is the trading name for a cyanide-based gas that was the preferred murder weapon used in the Nazi concentration camp gas chambers. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," an enhanced version of the gas, Zyklon D, has been invented for extermination on a smaller scale, which was odorless and sent victims to sleep rather than forcing them to endure the torturous suffocation experienced by those in the camps.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the recording of "Strange Fruit" being played by Joe in the Neutral Zone would otherwise be banned in the Greater Nazi Reich for being performed by a black female (Billie Holiday) and written by a Jewish male (Able Meeropol).

The Reichsadler ('Imperial Eagle') has been on German crests for hundreds of years. It can be traced back to the banner of the Holy Roman Empire, and symbolizes courage, strength, and immortality. In 1935, Hitler ordered the Eagle and the Swastika to be combined, which would become the national emblem known as the Parteiadler ('Party's Eagle'). The main difference between the Reichsadler and the Parteiadler are the direction of the bird's heads: the Imperial Eagle looks to its left whereas the "Party's Eagle" looks to its right. In contrast to the proud Reichsadler, the Parteiadler takes on a more threatening stance; the wings are powerfully spread and the head on squatted shoulders has a menacing appearance. In the eagle's talons a wreath of oak leaves circles the Swastika.
In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," being the sons of Jewish immigrants, The Marx Brothers' work would be prohibited by the Greater Nazi Reich.

Execution by firing squad, is a method of capital punishment, particularly common in the military and in times of war. For the military this method is often the supreme punishment or disciplinary means employed by military courts for crimes such as cowardice, desertion, espionage, murder, mutiny or treason. In Japan the death penalty still exists, however by hanging rather than firing squad. Death by firing squad historically has been used mainly for military executions. In the world of ""The Man in the High Castle,"" the Kempeitai in the Japanese Pacific States would have adopted the firing squad to carry out executions when aligned rules with the Reich, in cases that did not require a trial.
